page.title: 11THE HONORARY SYSTEM
page.content: Local government in Jersey is quite different in organisation from that of England. It is based around the Parish, of which there are twelve. The head of the parish is the Constable. He is elected by the parishioners, and has a seat in The States of Jersey which is the Island's parliament. The Constable is, amongst other things, responsible law and order in the Parish. To help him with this he has a number of other men. They are called Centeniers, Vingteniers, and Constables Officers. All these posts are honorary positions, and are unpaid. The holders of these posts are proud to serve their Parish, they are following a tradition that goes back centuries. Although 'paid' police often deal with crime these days, the honorary police must still be involved often presenting prosecution cases.
